title: 103_hr3814
content: The "Disability Insurance Reform Act of 1994" includes reforms to monthly insurance benefits for disabilities involving substance abuse. This Act introduces additional rules for benefits suspension and continued payments during rehabilitation programs. Nonpayment of benefits due to substance abuse is also addressed. The "Disability Insurance Reform Act of 1994" introduces rules for suspending disability benefits for individuals determined to be drug addicts or alcoholics. Benefits can be reinstated after completing a 3-month outpatient rehabilitation program approved by the Secretary and showing progress towards recovery. The Disability Insurance Reform Act of 1994 allows for the suspension of disability benefits for individuals with drug or alcohol-related disabilities. Benefits can be reinstated after completing a 3-month treatment program and meeting recovery requirements set by the Secretary. The Disability Insurance Reform Act of 1994 allows for the suspension of disability benefits for individuals with drug or alcohol-related disabilities if they fail to continue treatment as required. No benefit based on disability shall be paid until the person completes the required treatment. The Disability Insurance Reform Act of 1994 allows for the suspension of disability benefits for individuals with drug or alcohol-related disabilities if they fail to continue treatment as required. No benefit based on disability shall be paid until the person completes the required treatment. Monthly insurance benefits under this title will be payable to individuals based on the wages and self-employment income of the disabled individual, even if benefits are not payable to the disabled individual. The Secretary will monitor and test individuals receiving benefits under this title who are required to undergo treatment. The Secretary will develop standards for drug and alcohol treatment programs and guidelines to review participants' progress. The Secretary must submit an annual report to Congress on activities related to ensuring compliance with treatment requirements for individuals receiving benefits under this title. Additionally, Section 226 of the title is amended to preserve Medicare benefits. Section 226 of the title is amended to preserve Medicare benefits for participants in certain programs. The amendments made by this section will apply to benefits payable for months beginning 90 or more days after the date of the enactment of this Act. SEC. 3. RESTRICTION OF FUTURE REPRESENTATIVE PAYEES TO GOVERNMENT AGENCIES, STATE-LICENCED OR CERTIFIED FACILITIES, OR STATE-BONDED OR LICENSED COMMUNITY-BASED NONPROFIT SOCIAL SERVICE AGENCIES. The Social Security Act is amended to restrict representative payees to qualified organizations, removing the option for individuals or other organizations to serve in this role. The Social Security Act is amended to limit representative payees to qualified organizations, defining them as agencies or facilities licensed by the state. The Social Security Act is amended to limit representative payees to qualified organizations, such as community-based nonprofit social service agencies bonded or licensed by the state. Amendments include changes to section 205(j)(2)(C) and authorization for fees in section 205(j)(4) of the Act. Amendments to the Social Security Act limit representative payees to qualified organizations, allowing them to collect a monthly fee not exceeding 10% of the benefit involved. Any agreement for a fee exceeding this amount is void and considered misuse of benefits. The amendments also replace "qualified organization" with "person" in certain sections. The amendments to the Social Security Act restrict representative payees to qualified organizations, with a monthly fee cap of 10% of the benefit. Any agreement for a fee exceeding this amount is void. The amendments also replace "qualified organization" with "person" in certain sections and remove subparagraph (D). The effective date for these changes is upon the enactment of the Act.
